title: Digit sum
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the digit sum of a <a href="natural%20number">natural number</a> in a given <a href="number%20base">number base</a> is the <a href="summation">sum</a> of all its <a href="numerical%20digit">digit</a>s. Extension to negative integers.
The digit sum can be extended to the negative integers by use of a <a href="signed-digit%20representation">signed-digit representation</a> to represent each integer.
Applications.
The concept of a decimal digit sum is closely related to, but not the same as, the <a href="digital%20root">digital root</a>, which is the result of repeatedly applying the digit sum operation until the remaining value is only a single digit. The digital root of any non-zero integer will be a number in the range 1 to 9, whereas the digit sum can take any value. Digit sums and digital roots can be used for quick <a href="divisibility%20rule">divisibility tests</a>: a natural number is divisible by 3 or 9 if and only if its digit sum (or digital root) is divisible by 3 or 9, respectively. For divisibility by 9, this test is called the rule of nines and is the basis of the <a href="casting%20out%20nines">casting out nines</a> technique for checking calculations.
Digit sums are also a common ingredient in <a href="checksum">checksum</a> algorithms to check the arithmetic operations of early computers. Earlier, in an era of hand calculation, suggested using sums of 50 digits taken from mathematical tables of <a href="logarithm">logarithm</a>s as a form of <a href="random%20number%20generation">random number generation</a>; if one assumes that each digit is random, then by the <a href="central%20limit%20theorem">central limit theorem</a>, these digit sums will have a random distribution closely approximating a <a href="Gaussian%20distribution">Gaussian distribution</a>.
The digit sum of the <a href="Binary%20numeral%20system">binary</a> representation of a number is known as its <a href="Hamming%20weight">Hamming weight</a> or population count; algorithms for performing this operation have been studied, and it has been included as a built-in operation in some computer architectures and some programming languages. These operations are used in computing applications including <a href="cryptography">cryptography</a>, <a href="coding%20theory">coding theory</a>, and <a href="computer%20chess">computer chess</a>.
<a href="Harshad%20number">Harshad number</a>s are defined in terms of divisibility by their digit sums, and <a href="Smith%20number">Smith number</a>s are defined by the equality of their digit sums with the digit sums of their <a href="integer%20factorization">prime factorizations</a>.
